Package io.permazen

Class DetachedJTransaction

java.lang.Object
io.permazen.JTransaction
io.permazen.DetachedJTransaction
All Implemented Interfaces:
Closeable, AutoCloseable
public class DetachedJTransaction extends JTransaction implements Closeable
A JTransaction that is not actually connected to a Permazen database instance, but instead exists just to hold objects in memory.

DetachedJTransactions are typically used to "snapshot" some portion of a normal JTransaction for later use. As with all transactions, each DetachedJTransaction contains its own object data.

For convenience, each JTransaction has a default, initially empty DetachedJTransaction instance associated with it; JObject.copyOut() copies objects there.

Because DetachedJTransactions live indefinitely, their objects can be used just like normal Java objects, outside of any regular transaction, yet all of the usual Permazen features such as indexing, listeners, validation, etc., continue to function normally.

Because they typically contain only a portion of the database's objects and therefore may have dangling references, the referential integrity function of @JField.allowDeleted() is disabled in DetachedJTransactions.

Other Uses

More general usage beyond copies of regular transactions is possible: an empty DetachedJTransaction can be created on the fly via JTransaction.createDetachedTransaction() and then used as simple in-memory transaction workspace. The resulting key/value pairs could then be (de)serialized and sent over the network; see for example JObjectHttpMessageConverter.

For KVDatabase's that support it, using the key/value store snapshot returned by KVTransaction.readOnlySnapshot() allows an efficient "copy" of the entire database into a DetachedJTransaction using Permazen.createDetachedTransaction().

See Also:

  • Permazen.createDetachedTransaction()

    • reset

      public void reset()
      Delete all objects contained in this detached transaction and reset it back to its initial state.

      It will contain schema meta-data but no objects.

    • commit

      public void commit()
      Commit this transaction.

      DetachedJTransactions do not support this method and will always throw UnsupportedOperationException.

      Overrides:
